THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VII.

NOVEMBER 20, 1902.

No. 3.

A NEWSPAPER MAN'S WARNING.

tV

IIEN I was at the University a dozen years ago there was no student
paper. There had been efforts to establish one, in two of which I took
part, but the faculty was not then in the mood and we applied in vain for
Permission to go ahead. Even our much-loved class annual, the first of the Hullabaloos, had many trials and tribulations before we finally produced it upon the
stage of Un:versity life. This little foreword in a reminiscential vein is only
penned because it serves to measure my gratification at the success which has
attained the publication of THE NEWS- LETTVR. I have always held to the theory
that a college paper, well-edited, may become a valuable aid in the development
Of that 'varsity spirit which seems essential to the growth and popularity of an
institution like the Johns Hopkins. This, I feel sure, has been proven by THE

NEWS LETTER.
I have been asked to write something for this issue of THE NEws-LETTER.
can think of nothing better than to contribute a leaf out of my own story as a
w.arning to some now in the University who have hopes and dreams of a certain
kind There is in every class a percentage—sometimes large, sometimes small—
who desire to win a name as writers and who are more than likely to consider
that newspaper work offers a means to that end. These are the men I want to
reach and to them I merely wish to say:
"Don't do it."
.
A man who enters the newspaper field with the idea of stepping thereby
into literature or into the writing of history or any other sort of book-making
that requires sustained attention to score success, will ultimately wake up to a
realization that his cherished volume has not been written, nor, for that mat'er,
has. any other volume been turne,1 out that adequately satisfies the ambitions
of its producer. Journalism is sometimes a stepping-stone to literature, but
more often it is a set-back. It gives a man a living, it trains him to write with
facility, but it exacts much of him. The hours of work, especially on a morning
newspaper, are long, and then there are frequent emergency demands beyond
this limit. How, then, is a man likely to find time to delve into literature,
except in a most dilettante way? After an arduous mental and physical strain
of ten, twelve or fourteen hours, is he in condition to do work whose promise
and whose originality will gain the approval of the gentlemen who read manuscripts for the magazines and the publishing houses? He may write, having
acquired ease and speed, but he can never hope to concentrate his spare time for
months upon something other than his work for the paper. The result is that
his note in literature is but the feeblest pipe, unnoticed beyond a circle of friends
and leading to no enduring reputation.
I

THE NEWS-LETTER.
I know that some will say that there are literary posts in connection with a
large daily newspaper. There are, for example, writers of editorials and of
dramatic criticisms, reviewers of books and writers of special articles of a semiliterary or semi-editorial character. While this is true, it is also obvious that
the newspaper publisher is not going to engage youths just out of college to fill
any of these posts. In fact, I may go farther and lay it down as a principle
born of long experience that the best men for all these posts are those who have
been "through the mill," who have had their notions tempered by actual rubbing up against all things and all men and who have gained thereby a certain
delicacy of newspaper touch that enables them to take the pulse of the public
and to weigh right and wrong, importance and insignificance, with the rapidity
of judgment which a daily paper requires. I know one exceptionally able editor
and one brilliant literary critic, neither of whom were ever reporters The critic
was secured by the paper solely by reason of his exceptional aptitude for his
particular work, and can do nothing else for the newspaper, while the editor has
confessed to me that he feels he would be more valuable if he posses:ed the
insight which reporting and editing alone can give.
It is evident, then, that the chance of entering newspaper life other than as
a reporter is about one in a hundred. The ninety-nine, therefore, can attain
the desirable posts only by the route from the bottom. I think all of them will
consider journalism "one demned grind" after two months. A wary city editor
is afraid to trust the raw hand on other than routine items, and even with these
it is annoying to be reminded that the point has been overlooked or that initials
are necessary for all names. After that, however, comes the insidiously attractive part of a reporter's life. He is "assigned" to stories" of importance; he
rubs'elbows with fatuous men of city and State, and interviews distinguished
visitors; he feels that he is behind the scenes while dozens of dramas are being
acted simultaneously, and he learns that the stage-manager is always more
important than the actors, while the scene-shifter is very likely to be so. He
is, in a word, an active and not unimportant participant in the full tide of human
life, and though his work is arduous and his hours long,there is sufficient variety
in his assignments, day by day, to keep him always interested in his work and
eager to do better than his rivals.
A newspaper office is, however, not entirely made up of reporters. There
must be a corps of editors to do nothing but edit; men to plan what reporters
and correspondents shall do; men to go over, read, correct and dress up the
volume of matter pouring in; men to take that edited copy, classify it by relative
importance and interest, and to select the best for publication and "make up"
the pages. None of these men, in a first-grade newspaper office, ever write
anything but head-lines and corrections. Their hours are long, often unusually
so, their work confining, often uninteresting. Probably nearly all of them
started into journalism to pass on to literature. They escaped the maelstrom
of the attractiveness of reporting only to find themselves engulfed in the vortex
of "copy-reading," Their "great book" is not likely to be written unless they
tear themselves from newspaper work. And that is difficult to men of thirty or
more, men probably with families dependent on their salaries.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

This question of remuneration also suggests an additional warning. After
a college man who has gone into newspaper work has become broken in, his salary
will average from $800 to $1500 as a reporter, comparing more than favorably
with the incomes of his classmates who have gone into other professions. If he
becomes an editor, or an editorial writer, he will get from $1200 to $2000, and
this, too, may be still better than his classmates are doing. But that is his
maximum, and in eight or ten years the classmates, those who are ambitious
and successful, begin to forge ahead; as a rule, to stay ahead. The editor with
a comfortable salary will stay an editor of modest means all his life. He has
not the capital to branch out in the line whose details he has mastered, for it
takes a big sum to start a daily paper. He has to be content with the praises
of those who employ him and those who know him. His work is hidden in the
anonymity of each issue of his journal. His ambitions are for the paper. He
belongs to an honorable profession and he is respected, therefore, in the corn.
munity.
But he never writes that world-illumining volume if he continues to work
conscientiously as a newspaper man.
CHARLES WEATHERS BUMP, '92.

INTERCLASS FOOTBALL.

a1

,0 one will doubt but that the interclass football games played by the classes
of '92, '93 and '94 were beyond all expectations a great success, and if
by recalling them to mind after several years have elapsed, I can a'rouse
any enthusiasm along this line of University athletics, I shall have been fully
compensated for the time spent in writing these few lines.
For several years prior to '92 there had been class football teams, and they
continued to form a part of University athletics until after the freshman year of
the class of '94. At this time they were abolished and a University team put in the
field. These class teams aroused a great amount of college spirit, and in my humble opinion the formation of a University football team was directly traceable to
their organization. Class spirit and pride reached their culmination
in the clases of '92, '93 ' and '94, and when I think of the splendid
games played, I wonder how it came about that we could procure three such
teams out of so small a number of students I do not believe the teams that
formed the Interclass League for the winter of '91-'92 have ever been equalled
in any university, certainly never in the history of the Hopkins. Of course I
may be a more or less interested party, but I am sure the above is the general
opinion of those who know something of the history of these classes.
Nearly everyone is familiar with the history of the exciting games by which
'93 became the champions of the J. H.; '92 and '94 fought furiously for the
laurels, but were doomed to disappointment. There were but three games
Played, so that each class had a fair chance, and it hurt the pride of '92 to meet
defeat at the hands of the Junior class. '94 had not much to lose, for she was

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

too young in University life to appreciate the significance of such an event. In
honor of winning this championship, each member of the team of the class of
'93 was given as a trophy a golden football with his name and class engraved
upon it. These little charms are highly prized by the men holding them and
are afterward pointed to with much pride.
I have thus briefly given a mere outline of what has been done in class
athletics at the University. Why cannot this spirit again be revived? I
trust that the day will come when each class, as it enters the University, will
organize for athletics with the same feeling with which it organizes for protection against hazing, and that we will be able to witness the enthusiasm of a
decade ago.

H. N. A13F,RCRO1BIF.,
Captain of '93 Football Team.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
FOR THE UNDERGRADUATE.

C

HE Junidr-Freshman football game and cane-rush will again take up a
large share of the interest in fall athletics. The contests are scheduled
for December 6 at American League Park. As usual, half a dozen tickets
will be issued to each member of the two classes. Others wishing to secure
invitations should apply to G. A. Foster, '04, manager of the Junior team, or
Clarence Stone, '05, captain of the Freshman team.

The opening Musical Club concert took place on the afternoon of yesterday,
November 19, at the Hospital, the management following the usual wise plan
of selecting for the first audience those who are too weak to help themselves or
to protest. The choice of the Hospital is, in addition, fortunate in that many
of the old grads and former players on the clubs, who are now at the Medical
School, drop in and generously bestow their criticism upon the players. It
must be said, however, that the general result of the afternoon's work was
good, and that the leaders have cause to hope—which is about all that can be
expected of a first attempt. The program was as follows:
Glee Club, University Ode, Devries, '89; Banjo Club, March Song from
"The Show Girl;" Mandolin Club, "Imperial Edward March." Sousa; Glee
Club, 1902 medley, W. B Carver; Banjo Club, "Our Director" (Yale song);
Mandolin Club, March from "Prince of Pilsen;" Glee Club, "Wandering
Singers' Patrol;" Banjo Club,' The Ragged Raglan," Edgeworth Smith '98; Solo,
P. K. Gilman, Med.; Glee Club,'Rah for Black and Blue," J. G. Peters, '97.
On Monday night the members of the Senior Club assembled at that haunt
Of harmony for the second feast of the season, at which they were the guests of
the newly elected class president, Harry King Tootle. After reading the
stringent House Rules, posted by the vigilant committee, the Seniors indulged
in a little decorous "rough•house," during which a prominent member of the
lacrosse team was repeatedly called to order for his violation of Rule 5*. With
appetites .sharpened by these innocent diversions, the crowd next attacked a
bountiful "spread," and then retired to the rear to drink the health of the host
of the evening. A short business meeting of the Club followed.
"Resolved, That import duties on necessities of life should be materially
reduced," will be the subjett of the next debate by the Senate and the House.
In the Senate, the negative will be taken by Lanier, Hunley and Sandrock,
and the affirmative by Smith, Hoffman and Warner; while in the House, Foster
Erlanger and Evans will uphold the affirmative side and HumriChouse, Geiger
and Etnig the negative.
The University of North Carolina has submitted the following question as
the possible subject of their debate with tile Hopkins: "Resolved, That the
Patriot should be independent of party authority in voting." We have the
choice of defending either the negative or affirmative; but Dr. Lee feels that the
subject is perhaps not the best one for the case, and another one may be chosen.

HE leading article of this issue is from the pen of an alumnus who, ever
since his career as editor-in chief of the first HULLABALOO, has always
been strongly interested in Hopkins literary and journalistic affairs.
Perhaps even the convincing facts that he marshals so effectively will not hold
the members of the Press Club back from their awful fate; but in the case of
underclassmen with reportorial ambitions, there may still be hope. We congratulate the readers of THE NEWS-LETTER on having such an able intro
duction to this timely subject.

t

HE support given the football team by the college men and some faithful
grads. was very gratifying at the Westminster game. The number and
spirit of the rooters was good, and there is no doubt that their vigorous
and well-trained songs and war-cries helped the team to render so good an account of themselves. Moreover, from present indications it seems that a large
proportion of the college will be at the American League Park on Saturday,
to get in good training for the great fight on Thanksgiving day.
However, there are many men in the college who can help the team in a
more direct way than by yelling at it, and who are not taking advantage of
their opportunity. These are the men who should be composing the scrub
team. It has rarely happened this season that, in their afternoon practice, the
'Varsity players have had a second team to line up against, on which to try

Z

THE N EWS- LETT8R.
their plays. This is but a poor state of affairs. There are plenty of men who
could make their class teams, and who have some knowledge of football, who
are failing in their duty to the college, merely because they see no direct reward
for the exertion of coming out every afternoon and being rolled around by the
'Varsity players. It should need no second thought to show that there is as
little truth in such reasoning as there is honor in such a position. Although
the 'Varsity team is now made up, supposedly, of the best players that can
Possibly be secured from the college and Medical School, still it is the interest
and pride of every student to do all in his power to make them steadily better.
And if it is in his power to give such active help as practising with the regular
team, and if he does this faithfully, he will certainly deserve and obtain a
respect and popularity among his fellow-students which cannot be measured
by formal athletic honors. Every man who is able ought to get out his football clothes every afternoon during the week that remains before Thanksgiving,
and show some practical evidence of his gratitude to his Alma Mater.

4 40N to Homewood!" is still the cry. And it is being taken up by new
voices. The decision as to the dividing line between the University
grounds and the new city park settles an important question. Mr. Brent
Keyser, in supplying funds for the survey, is enabling us to get an idea as to how
our future temples of learning are to be placed. The latest agitation on the movement, however, is one which peculiarly interests the undergraduates, since it
must be carried out by them alone,— namely, the plan of a college dormitory,
to be built by Hopkins undergraduates by means of the dime savings-bank
system. It is astonishing how soon the dimes received in small change will
grow into the $5.00 which fills the bank; little burden would be experienced in
subscribing, say, $10.00 a year, even by those of least means. It is easy to cal
ciliate that 150 students, each giving $10.00 per year, would in the course of six
years accumulate the sum of $9,000, which with compound interest, would
approach $10,000. And this sum would be sufficient to erect a college dormitory at Homewood which would be a splendid memorial to the college
students of the J. H. U. from '02 to '08. As to the supervision of the matter,
the four class treasurers could form a perpetual committee to collect the money
and take charge of the deposit. To start this movement would be an achievement of which the present college could always feel proud, and with good
reason.

R. TOYOKICHI IYENTAGA, who lectured in the city last week. spent
some time about the University renewing old acquaintances.
Dr. Lyman Tyler, son of former President Tyler, will deliver the course of
lectures to be given at the University next February under the auspices of the
Maryland Society of Colonial Dames of America,
Dr. A. Marshall Elliott is on the committee on membership of the recently
organized "North Carolina Society."
The lectures on American history by Professor Andrew C. McLaughlin, of
University
of Michigan, have been postponed to November 24th and 25th.

Dr. McLaughlin will speak on "The Principles and Politics of the American
Revolution."
Dr. Paul Haupt, director of the Oriental Seminary, and Dr. T. C. Foote,
Rayner Fellow in the Oriental Seminary, are organizing a class in Elementary
Hebrew for ministers, theological students, and others interested in the sacred
Ian guage.
President Remsen delivered an address on "Original Research" before the
Association of Collegiate Alum= in Washington on last Friday.
At the annual meeting of the Charity Organization Society last week, President Remsen was elected president, and Dr. Gilman, vice-president. Dr. Remsen, Dr. Hurd and Dr. Hollander were elected members of the board of man•
agers. The annual public meeting of the society will be held at McCoy Hall,
Monday, December 1st. Addresses will be delivered by Rev. Dean Hodges, of
the Cambridge Divinity School, on "Alms and the Man," and by Mr. Edwin T.
Devine, General Secretary of the New York Charity Organization Society, on
"Reasons for and the Possibilities of the Federation."
The sixteenth annual convention of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of
the Middle States and Maryland will be held at McCoy Hall on November 28th
and 29th. President Remsen will deliver the address of welcome to the delegates. The last time the association met in Baltimore was in 1894.
Mr. John C. Thomas has been elected by the Hospital Trustees to the post
of Treasurer of the Johns Hopkins Hospital. Mr. Thomas fills the place of
Mr. Joseph C. Merrifield, who died last July.

The Geographical Society of Baltimore has received a great many recruits
from the student body on account of the connection of President-Emeritus
Gilman and others with the society. The members on Monday last numbered
1,131. The lectures will not be held in McCoy Hall, as originally announce
d,
but will take place at the Peabody Institute.
Prof. G. W. Ritchey, of the Yerkes Observatory and the University of Chicago, has accepted an invitation to lecture before a special meeting of the Scien
tific Association on the evening of Tuesday, the 25th. Subject: "Recent
Results in Astronomical Photography with the large instruments of the Yerkes
Observatory." Prof. Ritchey will show stereopticon pictures of some of these
wonderful photographs, and will explain the construction and operation of the
instruments used in taking them.
The fall meeting of the National Academy of Sciences was of especial in
terest to Hopkins men, not only because it was held in a University building,
but also because several papers, among them perhaps the most important of
the
session, were read by workers at the University. These were Dr. Morse and
Dr. R. W. Wood, who received great applause for their lectures and
demonstrations. Dr. Wood explained the nature of a substance long sought for by scientists, which he had successfully investigated, designated by him as nitroso dimethylaniline. Its use will be in the field of astronomical photography, arising
from its extraordinary property of opaqueness to all visible rays of light,
and
transparence to invisible rays.
Y. M. C. A. NOTES.

C

HE services of the Week of Prayer for young men were fairly well attended, and the spirit of the attendance was very good. President Remsen and Dean Griffin were both present at the Sunday meeting.
All men with nine o'clock classes have been urged to come a few minutes
early for morning prayer service. The singing at this service is good, but
more vOices would improve it. Dr. T. C. Foote leads this week and Mr. A. H.
Clarke will be the leader next week.
There is an interesting article in the November number of "Association
Men." It gives a list and personal account, with some photographs, of leading college athletes who are leaders of the Christian Associations of their colleges Some of these men were met by the Hopkins delegates at Northfield
last summer. Carter, of the Harvard Lacrosse team, was secretary of the Y.
M. C. A. for two years and is now student secretary for northern India.
France, captain of the Harvard baseball team and leader in Bible class work,
was one of the most active men at Northfield for positive Christian work.
Gardner, captain of the Princeton football team and member of the '03 crew, is
president of the Association. Joe McCracken is general secretary at Columbia.
Chadwick, captain of Yale's great eleven, is a leader in Christian work at Yale,
and had charge of the athletic events at Northfield. A copy of the article here
outlined is on the Y. M. C. A. bulletin board, or may be found on the reading
room table in Levering Hall.

Nov. 22—Maryland Agricultural College, at American League Park.

HOPKINS, 6; WESTERN MARYLAND, 6.
LL things considered, we have cause to be proud of ourselves for the
showing made in our first game of the season at Westminster.
Upon reaching there, it was decided that the game should be played
in two 20-minute halves. Hopkins won the toss, and decided to defend the
west goal.
Roberts kicked off for Western Maryland. Strohbar received the ball and
advanced it 10 yards. Miller made a run around right end for 15 yards, but at
this point Western Maryland braced up and secured the ball on downs.
The college boys played hard, but a fumble gave Yearley the opportunity
the ball for Hopkins. A series of fine runs by Blanck, Houghton and
secure
to
Miller carried the ball to Western Maryland's 20-yard line. Hopkins then lost
it on downs, but Maryland was forced to kick after being held for two downs.
Strohbar caught the ball, and by a beautiful run around right end advanced
the ball to the 15-yard line. Blanck was pushed through several times, and
finally, after a hard plunge, scored the first touchdown. He also kicked goal,
and after 18 minutes of play the score stood 6 to 0 in favor of Hopkins. The
remaining two minutes of the first half were spent in struggles which left the
ball in the center of the field.
Hopkins kicked off in the second half, and the ball was downed on the 10yard line. Western Maryland kept the ball most of the time, and fifteen seconds before the end of the game Roberts was pushed over for a touchdown near
the side lines. After a long and serious argument, Spalding's "Manual" prevailed, and the ball was punted out, successfully heeled, and Roberts kicked
goal, making the score 6 to 6.
Ten seconds remained, and on the first down after the kick-off, time was
called and the contest was over.

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

11

The game was snappy and full of spirit from start to finish. The end runs
and rushes made by Blanck, Miller and Stone were fine. In fact, these three
backs did nearly all the work of advancing the ball. Strohbar at quarterback
contributed largely to Hopkins' success. Thanks to his accuracy, Hopkins did
not make a fumble throughout the entire game. On Western Maryland's side,
Roberts, Hurley and Tarr played an excellent game, especially the first named.
We have good reasons to be proud of the 'Varsity eleven. It is no small
matter for players of comparatively green material to "split even" with a team
outweighing them by 16 pounds per man and playing on its own grounds.
The rooters which went up with the team on a special car contributed
largely to our success, for whenever they could take their eyes off the fair
co eds on the grand-stand they certainly did make a vast volume of encouraging noise.
Chief Rooter Plaggemeyer is to be congratulated upon his success in getting the rooting so well organized in such a short time, and every man in the
University should be on hand at the game with the Maryland Agricultural
College on Saturday next to cheer the Black and Blue on to victory.

TRACK TEAM

t

HE prospect before the management of the Track team is very encouraging.
Judging by the number of candidates who have turned out at Captain R.
C. Hoffman's call—some of them experienced track men—there should
be no difficulty in selecting a fast team to represent Hopkins at the several indoor meets this winter, and at the outdoor games next spring. Captain Hoffman expects, indeed, to develop as fast a team this year as ever turned out.
•

12

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Light practice, for some time, will prevail. The candidates appear on
the track three afternoons a week, and the two remaining afternoons are devoted to light gymnasium work for the systematic strengthening of the body.
A large proportion of the Freshman class have turned out, and under the
direction of Mr. Mackdertnott and Captain Hoffman, the men are gradually
losing their awkwardness. They will be instructed in the finer points when
they have developed some "form."
Hard work will begin about the first of December. The men will devote
their time to the weights and pulleys in the track room, and will work on the
track, in preparation for the interclass games to be held in the cage about the
end of January. Definite arrangements for this meet have not yet been made.
Two men will be elected by each class to confer with the track and field man
agement—Captain Hcfftnan, Manager Murkland, and Trainer Mackdermott—
concerning the final arrangements to be worked out. There will be the usual track
and field events and an interclass relay race. A cup will be given to the victorious class in this event, and suitable prizes will be given to the winners of the
other events. There is also some talk of a relay race between the Freshmen
and Juniors if the two classes desire it.
There will be several excellent men from the Medical School seen on the
cinder path this winter. "Joe" England and "Bill" Hoffman will be the
standbys from the graduate department.
Among those who will appear from the Senior Class are R. C. Hoffman,
Tootle, Pessagno, Nelson, Blank, Yearley, and Smith. From the Junior Class:
LeCron, Porter, Emig, Kohn, Heald, Rosenheim and Branham. Among the
Freshmen now at work are: Dill, Boyd, Ullman, Pagon, Chistn, Hudgins,
Morse, Chambers, Goodenow, Bass, Zeigler, Mergenthaler, Super, Hull, and
R. C. Jackson.

CLASS AND INTERCOLLEGIATE DEBATES.

HILE, the interclass debates will not take place until some time in the
spring, the candidates for the Junior and Senior teams are already beginning to prepare for the event. Enough men from both classes have
presented themselves as candidates to secure representative teams.
In order to stimulate interest in the class debates, and especially in the intercollegiate debates, a meeting of students was held November 12th to reorganize the Hopkins Debating Club. Sol Blum, '03, who was vice-president of
the society last year, presided, and explained the objects of the club. Two intercollegiate debates will be held this year, one with the University of North
Carolina, and the other witb Brown or Columbia. The election of officers for
the ensuing year resulted as follows: President, Sol Blum, '03; Vice-President,
Geo. A. Foster, '04; Secretary, L. W. Wallis,'04.

FABLES FOR THE FOOLISH.
In Words of a Few Syllables.

THE FABLE OP THE PHILANTHROPIST AND THE HO!) HANDLER.

HERE was once a well-meaning philanthropist who took a bath every
morning and employed a clerk to figure out his income. One hot summer
. day he sat in the shade of a venerable oak watching a house which was
being built across the street from his home. He was waiting for his coachman
to bring around his high-steppers, for that afternoon he intended to arouse some
dust and some envy on the speedway.
As he watched the sons of Ham carry the brick up the ladder he fell into a
Ponder, and from the ponder he fell into a soliloquy. "How much happier,"
quoth he, "are these men than I. How much they are to be envied. Behold!
they have the digestion of an ostrich and the sleep of a little child." Here he
heaved a sigh such as we are accustomed to hear on the stage. Growing bolder,
he advanced to one of the blackamoors who happened to be enjoying a short
rest in the shade, and addressed him thus:
"0 bow much better your lot is than mine! You know the joy of walking,
while I—I have to go whithersoever my coachman listeth. You eat whatever
your good wife puts into your till bucket, while I—I find the things prepared
by my French chef pall upon me. In the evening you go home and lie down to
peaceful slumbers. while I—I lie awake pondering what Pierpont Morgan is
going to do next."
Here did he heave another sigh The human edition of a work steer looked
at him in surprise. But the philanthropist continued his Sunday school con,
much after this fashion :
"See how gcod it is to labor. Verily I say unto you, if I or some of my
fellows could carry your hod for you and enjoy your peace, willingly would our
dollars be rained upon you in recompense."
The man who worked eight hours a day for one twenty-five could stand it
no longer.
"Look a heall, man, don' you know I'se willin' to trade? I knows de joy
oh walkin' does I? Huh! You carry a forty-pound hod up a ladder an' tell me
Where de joy comes in. I eats what my ole woman gives me, does I? I recken
hit ain't too much. Jes gimme a shot at dat French chief, an' I'll show him.
Don' talk ter me erbout Pierpoiit Morgen! He can have all de res' ob de won',
ef I wuz in your place. I sleeps lak a chile, does I? Don' you know, man, I'se
SO tired at night I can't eat tell mos' ten o'clock, an' in de mawnin' I'se so stiff
I can hardly walk. And yet you sez I've a good thing."
But the philanthropist stcod up for his pet theory. For the last time he
sighed.
"How happy one of my station would be if he could trade his dollars for
your contentment. Only," he added sadly, "he would not have the strength
to hold up the hod."

14

THE NEWS-LETTER.

"Don' let dat worry you," said the dusky son of toil. "Ef any ob dem
billionaires wants ter trade der dollars fer my hod, jes let 'em come eroun'. Ef
hits too heavy, I'll hold it up fer him."
MORAL. This fable teaches freshmen that contentment is an illusive
thing.

WALTER'S WISDOM.
443'I' was as good as a vic'try, sah," said Walter, as I climbed into the
throne-seat in his chamber of horrors. I let him explain.
'`Ef we'd been a-playin' on a billiard table insted of on .the side of a
mountain, sah, thar'd been nothin' doin'. You see, it was this way.'' Here
Walter made a dramatic sweep with his razor which threatened to decapitate me.
"It's jest like this, sah. Here's the side of the hill, here's them fellers, here's
the ball, and here we is. What next?" Walter backed off and looked at me
questioningly while he made an impressive oratorical pause. "What next?
What made'm tie that score? Gravity, sah, gravity. You know that things are
boun' to roll down hill. That ball jest had to come down. Them fellers didn't
tie the score; it was gravity, sah, gravity."
There was an impressive silence, broken only by the rasping sound which
told the loafers in the barber shop that Walter was giving me a close shave for
Sunday. I didn't need to be told.
"I've been paintin', sah," Walter remarked at last when he saw that I was
blissfully oblivious to my surroundings. I opened one eye and looked at him.
After examining him closely I calmly closed my eye and ventured to state that
I saw no traces of it, that he still preserved that healthy brown color which I so
admired. "If that is nature, Walter," I said, "it is good, but if it is art, it is
much better."
If ever Walter came near cutting my throat that was the time. When he
had gained control of his feelings he remonstrated. "Law! sah, I ain't been
paintin' myself, but the shop, sah. Can't you smell it?"
"I have detected a peculiar odor, Walter," I replied, "but I thought that
it was only your famous elixir for denuded roofs, otherwise known as hair-oil."
"What, sah, what! Ef you would use some of my hair restorer, it would
do you good."
"Then why don't you use it, Walter?"
"It's no use, sah," he answered, sadly shaking his head, "it's no use
Hair restorer can't help my bald head My wife done took all my hair out
before I invented my hair-oil "
Walter seemed to stand in need of consolation, but just then the bell rang
and I fled.

The Harvard Lamftoon is far from Dr. Griffin's course, but—
"We now come to Thales, the Milesian, who imagined the world to be of
water. He was undeceived by the Milesian authorities, who made him swim
over a steep hill and drink a glass of pebbles. His successor, Annexchimneys,
said that air was the only substance, whereupon he received a bill for clothing
which, his tailor declared, had been made to order from high-grade, hand-woven
air, warranted fast colors. Annexchimneys paid the bill, and thereafter kept
his theories to himself."
"Bughousides, of the Rheumatic school, maintained that empty space and
non-being cannot exist. His rival, Embezzlecheese, proved the existence of
empty space by pushing Bughousides out of a third-story window. Meeting
him soon after, Embezzlecheese inquired if he were well. 'I am not,' said the
great Rheumatic stiffly. 'You must be,' retorted Embezzlecheese,'non-being is
impossible.' And he dodged the brick which the enraged Bughousides sent
after him "

THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VII.

NOVEMBER 20, 1902.

No. 3.

A NEWSPAPER MAN'S WARNING.

tV

IIEN I was at the University a dozen years ago there was no student
paper. There had been efforts to establish one, in two of which I took
part, but the faculty was not then in the mood and we applied in vain for
Permission to go ahead. Even our much-loved class annual, the first of the Hullabaloos, had many trials and tribulations before we finally produced it upon the
stage of Un:versity life. This little foreword in a reminiscential vein is only
penned because it serves to measure my gratification at the success which has
attained the publication of THE NEWS- LETTVR. I have always held to the theory
that a college paper, well-edited, may become a valuable aid in the development
Of that 'varsity spirit which seems essential to the growth and popularity of an
institution like the Johns Hopkins. This, I feel sure, has been proven by THE

NEWS LETTER.
I have been asked to write something for this issue of THE NEws-LETTER.
can think of nothing better than to contribute a leaf out of my own story as a
w.arning to some now in the University who have hopes and dreams of a certain
kind There is in every class a percentage—sometimes large, sometimes small—
who desire to win a name as writers and who are more than likely to consider
that newspaper work offers a means to that end. These are the men I want to
reach and to them I merely wish to say:
"Don't do it."
.
A man who enters the newspaper field with the idea of stepping thereby
into literature or into the writing of history or any other sort of book-making
that requires sustained attention to score success, will ultimately wake up to a
realization that his cherished volume has not been written, nor, for that mat'er,
has. any other volume been turne,1 out that adequately satisfies the ambitions
of its producer. Journalism is sometimes a stepping-stone to literature, but
more often it is a set-back. It gives a man a living, it trains him to write with
facility, but it exacts much of him. The hours of work, especially on a morning
newspaper, are long, and then there are frequent emergency demands beyond
this limit. How, then, is a man likely to find time to delve into literature,
except in a most dilettante way? After an arduous mental and physical strain
of ten, twelve or fourteen hours, is he in condition to do work whose promise
and whose originality will gain the approval of the gentlemen who read manuscripts for the magazines and the publishing houses? He may write, having
acquired ease and speed, but he can never hope to concentrate his spare time for
months upon something other than his work for the paper. The result is that
his note in literature is but the feeblest pipe, unnoticed beyond a circle of friends
and leading to no enduring reputation.
I

THE NEWS-LETTER.
I know that some will say that there are literary posts in connection with a
large daily newspaper. There are, for example, writers of editorials and of
dramatic criticisms, reviewers of books and writers of special articles of a semiliterary or semi-editorial character. While this is true, it is also obvious that
the newspaper publisher is not going to engage youths just out of college to fill
any of these posts. In fact, I may go farther and lay it down as a principle
born of long experience that the best men for all these posts are those who have
been "through the mill," who have had their notions tempered by actual rubbing up against all things and all men and who have gained thereby a certain
delicacy of newspaper touch that enables them to take the pulse of the public
and to weigh right and wrong, importance and insignificance, with the rapidity
of judgment which a daily paper requires. I know one exceptionally able editor
and one brilliant literary critic, neither of whom were ever reporters The critic
was secured by the paper solely by reason of his exceptional aptitude for his
particular work, and can do nothing else for the newspaper, while the editor has
confessed to me that he feels he would be more valuable if he posses:ed the
insight which reporting and editing alone can give.
It is evident, then, that the chance of entering newspaper life other than as
a reporter is about one in a hundred. The ninety-nine, therefore, can attain
the desirable posts only by the route from the bottom. I think all of them will
consider journalism "one demned grind" after two months. A wary city editor
is afraid to trust the raw hand on other than routine items, and even with these
it is annoying to be reminded that the point has been overlooked or that initials
are necessary for all names. After that, however, comes the insidiously attractive part of a reporter's life. He is "assigned" to stories" of importance; he
rubs'elbows with fatuous men of city and State, and interviews distinguished
visitors; he feels that he is behind the scenes while dozens of dramas are being
acted simultaneously, and he learns that the stage-manager is always more
important than the actors, while the scene-shifter is very likely to be so. He
is, in a word, an active and not unimportant participant in the full tide of human
life, and though his work is arduous and his hours long,there is sufficient variety
in his assignments, day by day, to keep him always interested in his work and
eager to do better than his rivals.
A newspaper office is, however, not entirely made up of reporters. There
must be a corps of editors to do nothing but edit; men to plan what reporters
and correspondents shall do; men to go over, read, correct and dress up the
volume of matter pouring in; men to take that edited copy, classify it by relative
importance and interest, and to select the best for publication and "make up"
the pages. None of these men, in a first-grade newspaper office, ever write
anything but head-lines and corrections. Their hours are long, often unusually
so, their work confining, often uninteresting. Probably nearly all of them
started into journalism to pass on to literature. They escaped the maelstrom
of the attractiveness of reporting only to find themselves engulfed in the vortex
of "copy-reading," Their "great book" is not likely to be written unless they
tear themselves from newspaper work. And that is difficult to men of thirty or
more, men probably with families dependent on their salaries.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

This question of remuneration also suggests an additional warning. After
a college man who has gone into newspaper work has become broken in, his salary
will average from $800 to $1500 as a reporter, comparing more than favorably
with the incomes of his classmates who have gone into other professions. If he
becomes an editor, or an editorial writer, he will get from $1200 to $2000, and
this, too, may be still better than his classmates are doing. But that is his
maximum, and in eight or ten years the classmates, those who are ambitious
and successful, begin to forge ahead; as a rule, to stay ahead. The editor with
a comfortable salary will stay an editor of modest means all his life. He has
not the capital to branch out in the line whose details he has mastered, for it
takes a big sum to start a daily paper. He has to be content with the praises
of those who employ him and those who know him. His work is hidden in the
anonymity of each issue of his journal. His ambitions are for the paper. He
belongs to an honorable profession and he is respected, therefore, in the corn.
munity.
But he never writes that world-illumining volume if he continues to work
conscientiously as a newspaper man.
CHARLES WEATHERS BUMP, '92.

INTERCLASS FOOTBALL.

a1

,0 one will doubt but that the interclass football games played by the classes
of '92, '93 and '94 were beyond all expectations a great success, and if
by recalling them to mind after several years have elapsed, I can a'rouse
any enthusiasm along this line of University athletics, I shall have been fully
compensated for the time spent in writing these few lines.
For several years prior to '92 there had been class football teams, and they
continued to form a part of University athletics until after the freshman year of
the class of '94. At this time they were abolished and a University team put in the
field. These class teams aroused a great amount of college spirit, and in my humble opinion the formation of a University football team was directly traceable to
their organization. Class spirit and pride reached their culmination
in the clases of '92, '93 ' and '94, and when I think of the splendid
games played, I wonder how it came about that we could procure three such
teams out of so small a number of students I do not believe the teams that
formed the Interclass League for the winter of '91-'92 have ever been equalled
in any university, certainly never in the history of the Hopkins. Of course I
may be a more or less interested party, but I am sure the above is the general
opinion of those who know something of the history of these classes.
Nearly everyone is familiar with the history of the exciting games by which
'93 became the champions of the J. H.; '92 and '94 fought furiously for the
laurels, but were doomed to disappointment. There were but three games
Played, so that each class had a fair chance, and it hurt the pride of '92 to meet
defeat at the hands of the Junior class. '94 had not much to lose, for she was

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

too young in University life to appreciate the significance of such an event. In
honor of winning this championship, each member of the team of the class of
'93 was given as a trophy a golden football with his name and class engraved
upon it. These little charms are highly prized by the men holding them and
are afterward pointed to with much pride.
I have thus briefly given a mere outline of what has been done in class
athletics at the University. Why cannot this spirit again be revived? I
trust that the day will come when each class, as it enters the University, will
organize for athletics with the same feeling with which it organizes for protection against hazing, and that we will be able to witness the enthusiasm of a
decade ago.

H. N. A13F,RCRO1BIF.,
Captain of '93 Football Team.

FOR THE UNDERGRADUATE.

HE Junidr-Freshman football game and cane-rush will again take up a
large share of the interest in fall athletics. The contests are scheduled
for December 6 at American League Park. As usual, half a dozen tickets
will be issued to each member of the two classes. Others wishing to secure
invitations should apply to G. A. Foster, '04, manager of the Junior team, or
Clarence Stone, '05, captain of the Freshman team.

The opening Musical Club concert took place on the afternoon of yesterday,
November 19, at the Hospital, the management following the usual wise plan
of selecting for the first audience those who are too weak to help themselves or
to protest. The choice of the Hospital is, in addition, fortunate in that many
of the old grads and former players on the clubs, who are now at the Medical
School, drop in and generously bestow their criticism upon the players. It
must be said, however, that the general result of the afternoon's work was
good, and that the leaders have cause to hope—which is about all that can be
expected of a first attempt. The program was as follows:
Glee Club, University Ode, Devries, '89; Banjo Club, March Song from
"The Show Girl;" Mandolin Club, "Imperial Edward March." Sousa; Glee
Club, 1902 medley, W. B Carver; Banjo Club, "Our Director" (Yale song);
Mandolin Club, March from "Prince of Pilsen;" Glee Club, "Wandering
Singers' Patrol;" Banjo Club,' The Ragged Raglan," Edgeworth Smith '98; Solo,
P. K. Gilman, Med.; Glee Club,'Rah for Black and Blue," J. G. Peters, '97.
On Monday night the members of the Senior Club assembled at that haunt
Of harmony for the second feast of the season, at which they were the guests of
the newly elected class president, Harry King Tootle. After reading the
stringent House Rules, posted by the vigilant committee, the Seniors indulged
in a little decorous "rough•house," during which a prominent member of the
lacrosse team was repeatedly called to order for his violation of Rule 5*. With
appetites .sharpened by these innocent diversions, the crowd next attacked a
bountiful "spread," and then retired to the rear to drink the health of the host
of the evening. A short business meeting of the Club followed.
"Resolved, That import duties on necessities of life should be materially
reduced," will be the subjett of the next debate by the Senate and the House.
In the Senate, the negative will be taken by Lanier, Hunley and Sandrock,
and the affirmative by Smith, Hoffman and Warner; while in the House, Foster
Erlanger and Evans will uphold the affirmative side and HumriChouse, Geiger
and Etnig the negative.
The University of North Carolina has submitted the following question as
the possible subject of their debate with tile Hopkins: "Resolved, That the
Patriot should be independent of party authority in voting." We have the
choice of defending either the negative or affirmative; but Dr. Lee feels that the
subject is perhaps not the best one for the case, and another one may be chosen.

HE leading article of this issue is from the pen of an alumnus who, ever
since his career as editor-in chief of the first HULLABALOO, has always
been strongly interested in Hopkins literary and journalistic affairs.
Perhaps even the convincing facts that he marshals so effectively will not hold
the members of the Press Club back from their awful fate; but in the case of
underclassmen with reportorial ambitions, there may still be hope. We congratulate the readers of THE NEWS-LETTER on having such an able intro
duction to this timely subject.

HE support given the football team by the college men and some faithful
grads. was very gratifying at the Westminster game. The number and
spirit of the rooters was good, and there is no doubt that their vigorous
and well-trained songs and war-cries helped the team to render so good an account of themselves. Moreover, from present indications it seems that a large
proportion of the college will be at the American League Park on Saturday,
to get in good training for the great fight on Thanksgiving day.
However, there are many men in the college who can help the team in a
more direct way than by yelling at it, and who are not taking advantage of
their opportunity. These are the men who should be composing the scrub
team. It has rarely happened this season that, in their afternoon practice, the
'Varsity players have had a second team to line up against, on which to try

Z

THE N EWS- LETT8R.
their plays. This is but a poor state of affairs. There are plenty of men who
could make their class teams, and who have some knowledge of football, who
are failing in their duty to the college, merely because they see no direct reward
for the exertion of coming out every afternoon and being rolled around by the
'Varsity players. It should need no second thought to show that there is as
little truth in such reasoning as there is honor in such a position. Although
the 'Varsity team is now made up, supposedly, of the best players that can
Possibly be secured from the college and Medical School, still it is the interest
and pride of every student to do all in his power to make them steadily better.
And if it is in his power to give such active help as practising with the regular
team, and if he does this faithfully, he will certainly deserve and obtain a
respect and popularity among his fellow-students which cannot be measured
by formal athletic honors. Every man who is able ought to get out his football clothes every afternoon during the week that remains before Thanksgiving,
and show some practical evidence of his gratitude to his Alma Mater.

4 40N to Homewood!" is still the cry. And it is being taken up by new
voices. The decision as to the dividing line between the University
grounds and the new city park settles an important question. Mr. Brent
Keyser, in supplying funds for the survey, is enabling us to get an idea as to how
our future temples of learning are to be placed. The latest agitation on the movement, however, is one which peculiarly interests the undergraduates, since it
must be carried out by them alone,— namely, the plan of a college dormitory,
to be built by Hopkins undergraduates by means of the dime savings-bank
system. It is astonishing how soon the dimes received in small change will
grow into the $5.00 which fills the bank; little burden would be experienced in
subscribing, say, $10.00 a year, even by those of least means. It is easy to cal
ciliate that 150 students, each giving $10.00 per year, would in the course of six
years accumulate the sum of $9,000, which with compound interest, would
approach $10,000. And this sum would be sufficient to erect a college dormitory at Homewood which would be a splendid memorial to the college
students of the J. H. U. from '02 to '08. As to the supervision of the matter,
the four class treasurers could form a perpetual committee to collect the money
and take charge of the deposit. To start this movement would be an achievement of which the present college could always feel proud, and with good
reason.

HE services of the Week of Prayer for young men were fairly well attended, and the spirit of the attendance was very good. President Remsen and Dean Griffin were both present at the Sunday meeting.

early for morning prayer service. The singing at this service is good, but
more vOices would improve it. Dr. T. C. Foote leads this week and Mr. A. H.
Clarke will be the leader next week.
There is an interesting article in the November number of "Association
Men." It gives a list and personal account, with some photographs, of leading college athletes who are leaders of the Christian Associations of their colleges Some of these men were met by the Hopkins delegates at Northfield
last summer. Carter, of the Harvard Lacrosse team, was secretary of the Y.
M. C. A. for two years and is now student secretary for northern India.
France, captain of the Harvard baseball team and leader in Bible class work,
was one of the most active men at Northfield for positive Christian work.
Gardner, captain of the Princeton football team and member of the '03 crew, is
president of the Association. Joe McCracken is general secretary at Columbia.
Chadwick, captain of Yale's great eleven, is a leader in Christian work at Yale,
and had charge of the athletic events at Northfield. A copy of the article here
outlined is on the Y. M. C. A. bulletin board, or may be found on the reading
room table in Levering Hall.

HOPKINS, 6; WESTERN MARYLAND, 6.
LL things considered, we have cause to be proud of ourselves for the
showing made in our first game of the season at Westminster.
Upon reaching there, it was decided that the game should be played
in two 20-minute halves. Hopkins won the toss, and decided to defend the
west goal.
Roberts kicked off for Western Maryland. Strohbar received the ball and
advanced it 10 yards. Miller made a run around right end for 15 yards, but at
this point Western Maryland braced up and secured the ball on downs.
The college boys played hard, but a fumble gave Yearley the opportunity
the ball for Hopkins. A series of fine runs by Blanck, Houghton and
secure
to
Miller carried the ball to Western Maryland's 20-yard line. Hopkins then lost
it on downs, but Maryland was forced to kick after being held for two downs.
Strohbar caught the ball, and by a beautiful run around right end advanced
the ball to the 15-yard line. Blanck was pushed through several times, and
finally, after a hard plunge, scored the first touchdown. He also kicked goal,
and after 18 minutes of play the score stood 6 to 0 in favor of Hopkins. The
remaining two minutes of the first half were spent in struggles which left the
ball in the center of the field.
Hopkins kicked off in the second half, and the ball was downed on the 10yard line. Western Maryland kept the ball most of the time, and fifteen seconds before the end of the game Roberts was pushed over for a touchdown near
the side lines. After a long and serious argument, Spalding's "Manual" prevailed, and the ball was punted out, successfully heeled, and Roberts kicked
goal, making the score 6 to 6.
Ten seconds remained, and on the first down after the kick-off, time was
called and the contest was over.

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

11

The game was snappy and full of spirit from start to finish. The end runs
and rushes made by Blanck, Miller and Stone were fine. In fact, these three
backs did nearly all the work of advancing the ball. Strohbar at quarterback
contributed largely to Hopkins' success. Thanks to his accuracy, Hopkins did
not make a fumble throughout the entire game. On Western Maryland's side,
Roberts, Hurley and Tarr played an excellent game, especially the first named.
We have good reasons to be proud of the 'Varsity eleven. It is no small
matter for players of comparatively green material to "split even" with a team
outweighing them by 16 pounds per man and playing on its own grounds.
The rooters which went up with the team on a special car contributed
largely to our success, for whenever they could take their eyes off the fair
co eds on the grand-stand they certainly did make a vast volume of encouraging noise.
Chief Rooter Plaggemeyer is to be congratulated upon his success in getting the rooting so well organized in such a short time, and every man in the
University should be on hand at the game with the Maryland Agricultural
College on Saturday next to cheer the Black and Blue on to victory.

TRACK TEAM

t

HE prospect before the management of the Track team is very encouraging.
Judging by the number of candidates who have turned out at Captain R.
C. Hoffman's call—some of them experienced track men—there should
be no difficulty in selecting a fast team to represent Hopkins at the several indoor meets this winter, and at the outdoor games next spring. Captain Hoffman expects, indeed, to develop as fast a team this year as ever turned out.
•

12

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Light practice, for some time, will prevail. The candidates appear on
the track three afternoons a week, and the two remaining afternoons are devoted to light gymnasium work for the systematic strengthening of the body.
A large proportion of the Freshman class have turned out, and under the
direction of Mr. Mackdertnott and Captain Hoffman, the men are gradually
losing their awkwardness. They will be instructed in the finer points when
they have developed some "form."
Hard work will begin about the first of December. The men will devote
their time to the weights and pulleys in the track room, and will work on the
track, in preparation for the interclass games to be held in the cage about the
end of January. Definite arrangements for this meet have not yet been made.
Two men will be elected by each class to confer with the track and field man
agement—Captain Hcfftnan, Manager Murkland, and Trainer Mackdermott—
concerning the final arrangements to be worked out. There will be the usual track
and field events and an interclass relay race. A cup will be given to the victorious class in this event, and suitable prizes will be given to the winners of the
other events. There is also some talk of a relay race between the Freshmen
and Juniors if the two classes desire it.
There will be several excellent men from the Medical School seen on the
cinder path this winter. "Joe" England and "Bill" Hoffman will be the
standbys from the graduate department.
Among those who will appear from the Senior Class are R. C. Hoffman,
Tootle, Pessagno, Nelson, Blank, Yearley, and Smith. From the Junior Class:
LeCron, Porter, Emig, Kohn, Heald, Rosenheim and Branham. Among the
Freshmen now at work are: Dill, Boyd, Ullman, Pagon, Chistn, Hudgins,
Morse, Chambers, Goodenow, Bass, Zeigler, Mergenthaler, Super, Hull, and
R. C. Jackson.

CLASS AND INTERCOLLEGIATE DEBATES.

HILE, the interclass debates will not take place until some time in the
spring, the candidates for the Junior and Senior teams are already beginning to prepare for the event. Enough men from both classes have
presented themselves as candidates to secure representative teams.
In order to stimulate interest in the class debates, and especially in the intercollegiate debates, a meeting of students was held November 12th to reorganize the Hopkins Debating Club. Sol Blum, '03, who was vice-president of
the society last year, presided, and explained the objects of the club. Two intercollegiate debates will be held this year, one with the University of North
Carolina, and the other witb Brown or Columbia. The election of officers for
the ensuing year resulted as follows: President, Sol Blum, '03; Vice-President,
Geo. A. Foster, '04; Secretary, L. W. Wallis,'04.

THE FABLE OP THE PHILANTHROPIST AND THE HO!) HANDLER.

HERE was once a well-meaning philanthropist who took a bath every
morning and employed a clerk to figure out his income. One hot summer
. day he sat in the shade of a venerable oak watching a house which was
being built across the street from his home. He was waiting for his coachman
to bring around his high-steppers, for that afternoon he intended to arouse some
dust and some envy on the speedway.
As he watched the sons of Ham carry the brick up the ladder he fell into a
Ponder, and from the ponder he fell into a soliloquy. "How much happier,"
quoth he, "are these men than I. How much they are to be envied. Behold!
they have the digestion of an ostrich and the sleep of a little child." Here he
heaved a sigh such as we are accustomed to hear on the stage. Growing bolder,
he advanced to one of the blackamoors who happened to be enjoying a short
rest in the shade, and addressed him thus:
"0 bow much better your lot is than mine! You know the joy of walking,
while I—I have to go whithersoever my coachman listeth. You eat whatever
your good wife puts into your till bucket, while I—I find the things prepared
by my French chef pall upon me. In the evening you go home and lie down to
peaceful slumbers. while I—I lie awake pondering what Pierpont Morgan is
going to do next."
Here did he heave another sigh The human edition of a work steer looked
at him in surprise. But the philanthropist continued his Sunday school con,
much after this fashion :
"See how gcod it is to labor. Verily I say unto you, if I or some of my
fellows could carry your hod for you and enjoy your peace, willingly would our
dollars be rained upon you in recompense."
The man who worked eight hours a day for one twenty-five could stand it
no longer.
"Look a heall, man, don' you know I'se willin' to trade? I knows de joy
oh walkin' does I? Huh! You carry a forty-pound hod up a ladder an' tell me
Where de joy comes in. I eats what my ole woman gives me, does I? I recken
hit ain't too much. Jes gimme a shot at dat French chief, an' I'll show him.
Don' talk ter me erbout Pierpoiit Morgen! He can have all de res' ob de won',
ef I wuz in your place. I sleeps lak a chile, does I? Don' you know, man, I'se
SO tired at night I can't eat tell mos' ten o'clock, an' in de mawnin' I'se so stiff
I can hardly walk. And yet you sez I've a good thing."
But the philanthropist stcod up for his pet theory. For the last time he
sighed.
"How happy one of my station would be if he could trade his dollars for
your contentment. Only," he added sadly, "he would not have the strength
to hold up the hod."

14

THE NEWS-LETTER.

"Don' let dat worry you," said the dusky son of toil. "Ef any ob dem
billionaires wants ter trade der dollars fer my hod, jes let 'em come eroun'. Ef
hits too heavy, I'll hold it up fer him."
MORAL. This fable teaches freshmen that contentment is an illusive
thing.

WALTER'S WISDOM.
443'I' was as good as a vic'try, sah," said Walter, as I climbed into the
throne-seat in his chamber of horrors. I let him explain.
'`Ef we'd been a-playin' on a billiard table insted of on .the side of a
mountain, sah, thar'd been nothin' doin'. You see, it was this way.'' Here
Walter made a dramatic sweep with his razor which threatened to decapitate me.
"It's jest like this, sah. Here's the side of the hill, here's them fellers, here's
the ball, and here we is. What next?" Walter backed off and looked at me
questioningly while he made an impressive oratorical pause. "What next?
What made'm tie that score? Gravity, sah, gravity. You know that things are
boun' to roll down hill. That ball jest had to come down. Them fellers didn't
tie the score; it was gravity, sah, gravity."
There was an impressive silence, broken only by the rasping sound which
told the loafers in the barber shop that Walter was giving me a close shave for
Sunday. I didn't need to be told.
"I've been paintin', sah," Walter remarked at last when he saw that I was
blissfully oblivious to my surroundings. I opened one eye and looked at him.
After examining him closely I calmly closed my eye and ventured to state that
I saw no traces of it, that he still preserved that healthy brown color which I so
admired. "If that is nature, Walter," I said, "it is good, but if it is art, it is
much better."
If ever Walter came near cutting my throat that was the time. When he
had gained control of his feelings he remonstrated. "Law! sah, I ain't been
paintin' myself, but the shop, sah. Can't you smell it?"
"I have detected a peculiar odor, Walter," I replied, "but I thought that
it was only your famous elixir for denuded roofs, otherwise known as hair-oil."
"What, sah, what! Ef you would use some of my hair restorer, it would
do you good."
"Then why don't you use it, Walter?"
"It's no use, sah," he answered, sadly shaking his head, "it's no use
Hair restorer can't help my bald head My wife done took all my hair out
before I invented my hair-oil "
Walter seemed to stand in need of consolation, but just then the bell rang
and I fled.

The Harvard Lamftoon is far from Dr. Griffin's course, but—
"We now come to Thales, the Milesian, who imagined the world to be of
water. He was undeceived by the Milesian authorities, who made him swim
over a steep hill and drink a glass of pebbles. His successor, Annexchimneys,
said that air was the only substance, whereupon he received a bill for clothing
which, his tailor declared, had been made to order from high-grade, hand-woven
air, warranted fast colors. Annexchimneys paid the bill, and thereafter kept
his theories to himself."
"Bughousides, of the Rheumatic school, maintained that empty space and
non-being cannot exist. His rival, Embezzlecheese, proved the existence of
empty space by pushing Bughousides out of a third-story window. Meeting
him soon after, Embezzlecheese inquired if he were well. 'I am not,' said the
great Rheumatic stiffly. 'You must be,' retorted Embezzlecheese,'non-being is
impossible.' And he dodged the brick which the enraged Bughousides sent
after him "
